awd_titl_txt: SaTC: EDU: CyCAD: A Virtual Platform for Cybersecurity Curriculum on Analog Design
awd_abstract_narration:
The understanding of the hardware security of digital systems has gained significant maturity through research and curriculum development.   However, most cybersecurity curricula fail to cover these threats.  This project will develop a virtual platform for a cybersecurity curriculum on analog design (CyCAD).  The curriculum will feature hands-on learning through planned activities, assessments, and projects on CyCAD test boards.  Students will learn core cybersecurity concepts using the CyCAD framework, which will be upgraded throughout the project for future use as a self-contained audio-visual learning package.  By providing remote access to CyCAD, and the flexibility to personalize experiments, the project will also address "Advance Personalized Learning," one of the National Academy of Engineering's Grand Challenges. This project will promote K-12 and technical workforce education, cybersecurity awareness in the society, and collaboration between computer science, electrical engineering and education.

The project features a strong K-12 outreach component that includes a professional development workshop for teachers.  A well-thought out, and carefully designed, dissemination plan that employs multiple approaches, including YouTube videos, will reach a broad range of individuals.  The project addresses a significant gap in cybersecurity education, and that the comprehensive K-12 outreach component, coupled with the multifaceted dissemination plan, will ensure that this project will have a significant impact well beyond the limits of the host institution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project is to develop and pilot a Do-It-Yourself modular Cybersecurity Curriculum on Analog Design (CyCAD) test board with accompanying modular curriculum. The objective is to enable the students to assemble modular hardware components, select appropriate test stimulus and even the analog design to run the desired cybersecurity experiment. CyCAD will also allow the students to learn the core concepts of analog cybersecurity and bind pedagogical techniques such as classroom flipping to create an engaging classroom environment. Towards this goal, we created modular boards to validate analog circuit designs and their security challenges. Undergraduate students were included in the research. A technical paper with undergraduate students won the Best Student Paper Award in American Society of Engineering Education (ASEE) Mid Atlantic Conference in 2021. The graduate level course on hardware security created by the PI employed the proposed board for hands-on experiments. Technical papers have been published on the security studies with the CyCAD board with graduate and undergraduate in major technical conferences and journals. One of these papers also won Best Paper Award in Work-in-Progress category in IEEE International Symposium on Quality Electronic Design, 2020.

On the broader impact side, a 4-day workshop has been hosted for school teachers with Penn State Center for Science and the Schools (CSATS) on spreading cybersecurity awareness. The workshop included lectures and hands-on experiments that were run by the graduate and undergraduate students. Teachers took pre- and post-concept inventories to assess their learning of content throughout the workshop and the results indicated improvement of 58%. The findings were published in Annual Conference of ASEE in 2020 and won the divisional Best Paper Award.

This project led to training of 10+ PhD students, 2 master’s students (both female) and 6 undergraduate students including 2 Honors students from Penn State Schreyer Honors College. The outcomes were published in 30+ IEEE/ACM conference and journal venues and resulted in several invention disclosures. The PI also educated the community about hardware security by organizing tutorials, short courses and special sessions in IEEE Design Automation Conference, IEEE Design Automation and Test in Europe Conference, IEEE International Conference on Computer-Aided Design and IEEE International Test Conference, to name a few, serving on panels and delivering invited lectures in various conferences and ACM Student Chapters.

The students working on this project received Nirmal Bose Outstanding Dissertation Award from Electrical Engineering Department at Penn State in 2019, TTTC Edward J. McClusky Outstanding Dissertation Award in 2020 and Penn State Alumni Society Outstanding Dissertation Award in 2022.

 


Last Modified: 09/10/2023
Modified by: Swaroop Ghosh
